heaviest_rainfall.status: The heaviest total rainfall occurred on 04 January 2025, dropping 36.8mm of rain over the 37.2 hour storm duration with a maximum rate of 4.6mm per hour.

heaviest_rainrate.status: The heaviest rain rate registered stands at 27.0mm per hour on 02 September 2025, highlighting an extreme precipitation event.  21.19mm fell during the storm over 15.0 hours.

longest_rain.status: Rain fell for 37.2 hours on 04 January 2025 creating a new record that still lasts.  The storm produced a total of 36.8mm with a maximum intensity of 4.6mm per hour.

most_lightning.status: The most lightning activity recorded in a single day is 23, which occurred on 07 September 2025 (since our records began on 11 April 2025).

storm.status: No stormy weather is anticipated.  The last big storm was recorded on 21 September 2025, lasting 1 day.

top_10_dry.status: The longest dry period started on 24 April 2025 and lasted for 19 days.

top_10_rainy.status: The longest rainy period started on 30 November 2024 and lasted for 10 days.

cold_snaps.status: At the moment, it is not a cold snap.  This year has seen 6 cold snaps; typically, 3.7 cold snaps happen every year.

extreme.status: The maximum temperature difference seen is 26.7°C, observed on 29 April 2025 when the temperature fell to 0.4°C but also managed to reach 27.1°C on the same day.

heatwaves.status: There is not a heatwaves right now.  There have been 6 this year, compared to a usual average of 1.9.

tropical.status: The last tropical night was 18 July 2025, there have been only 62 tropical nights since 1973.

average.status: The current average daily wind direction is southerly (188°).  In the UK, a southerly wind usually brings milder, moist air from the Atlantic.

gusts.status: The largest wind gust ever was on 13 October 2012 with a value of 93.7 mph.

run.status: The highest wind run ever seen is 1737 miles on 21 October 2012.

speed.status: The top recorded wind speed is 93.7 mph on 13 October 2012.

top_10_windy.status: The longest windy period started on 11 October 2012 and lasted for 21 days.

summary.description:
Compared to today, yesterday also had noticeable differences in pressure (down 9 mbar).

The past week and month had observable variation in dew point temperature (up 7.3°C), feels like temperature (up 9.1°C), outside temperature (up 6.1°C), and outside humidity (up 10%) when compared to today.

cloud levels.description:
Today’s average cloud levels is 127.6m higher than yesterday, 831.6m higher than the past week, 555.3m higher than the past month.

Yesterday, cloud levels hit a low of 1104m and a high of 3920m, averaging 2390m; the past week and month reported somewhat higher averages.
cloud levels.summary: The sky’s high clouds will permit plenty of sunshine.

summary.summary: Inside; temperatures should be quite comfortable. Outside; mild temperatures are expected. Also, the air will feel dry and calm and still conditions are expected. A few light raindrops may fall, the sky’s high clouds will permit plenty of sunshine, and sunlight levels will peak at very high intensity. High pressure will dominate, leading to stable weather.
